articles.headline: Judge Narrows Scope of Coming Trial Over Google Monopoly Claims
articles.snippet: The ruling did not affect some central parts of the antitrust cases about Google search, which are scheduled to go to trial next month.
articles.abstract: The ruling did not affect some central parts of the antitrust cases about Google search, which are scheduled to go to trial next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge said this week that the Justice Department and a group of states could not move forward with some claims in antitrust complaints against Google, narrowing the scope of what is set to be the most significant federal monopoly trial against a tech giant in decades.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Nico Grant

articles.headline: How Jack Smith Structured the Trump Election Indictment to Reduce Risks
articles.snippet: The special counsel layered varied charges atop the same facts, while sidestepping a free-speech question by not charging incitement.
articles.abstract: The special counsel layered varied charges atop the same facts, while sidestepping a free-speech question by not charging incitement.
articles.lead_paragraph: In accusing former President Donald J. Trump of conspiring to subvert American democracy, the special counsel, Jack Smith, charged the same story three different ways. The charges are novel applications of criminal laws to unprecedented circumstances, heightening legal risks, but Mr. Smith’s tactic gives him multiple paths in obtaining and upholding a guilty verdict.

articles.headline: Trump’s Legal Team Is Enmeshed in a Tangle of Possible Conflicts
articles.snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump’s growing cast of lawyers is marked by a web of overlapping interests encompassing witnesses, co-defendants and potential targets.
articles.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s growing cast of lawyers is marked by a web of overlapping interests encompassing witnesses, co-defendants and potential targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: M. Evan Corcoran, a lawyer who accompanied former President Donald J. Trump to court this week for his arraignment on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election, has given crucial evidence in Mr. Trump’s other federal case — the one accusing him of illegally hoarding classified documents.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: A Global Web of Chinese Propaganda Leads to a U.S. Tech Mogul
articles.snippet: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
articles.abstract: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The protest in London’s bustling Chinatown brought together a variety of activist groups to oppose a rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So it was peculiar when a street brawl broke out among mostly ethnic Chinese demonstrators.
articles.byline: By Mara Hvistendahl, David A. Fahrenthold, Lynsey Chutel and Ishaan Jhaveri

articles.headline: The Women’s Magazines of 2023 Are in a Facebook Group and Your Inbox
articles.snippet: People still want to know what to wear and what is actually worth buying — and they want to trust the person telling them.
articles.abstract: People still want to know what to wear and what is actually worth buying — and they want to trust the person telling them.
articles.lead_paragraph: What should a 33-year-old postpartum woman wear to her cousin’s 21st birthday party in New York City?

articles.headline: Big Tech Rebounds and Preps for Transformative A.I. Investments
articles.snippet: As the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on artificial intelligence, which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.
articles.abstract: As the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on artificial intelligence, which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, the tech industry’s prospects looked bleak. Google’s profit dropped. Shares of Facebook’s parent company, Meta, were in free fall. Business growth at Amazon had slowed to its lowest level in two decades.

articles.headline: ‘We Are Feeling Overpoliced’: State Troopers Join Patrols in Austin
articles.snippet: The city ended a partnership with the Texas Department of Public Safety this month after troubling incidents. In response, Gov. Greg Abbott sent in more troopers.
articles.abstract: The city ended a partnership with the Texas Department of Public Safety this month after troubling incidents. In response, Gov. Greg Abbott sent in more troopers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scores of state highway troopers, usually found on roadways across Texas in their distinctive cowboy hats and black-and-white patrol vehicles, have descended on Austin, the state capital.

articles.headline: Is It Possible to Buy a House in Your 20s? Yes, but Only With Some Help.
articles.snippet: For some young people, a path to homeownership often involves a mix of diligent saving combined with assistance from family or government loans and programs.
articles.abstract: For some young people, a path to homeownership often involves a mix of diligent saving combined with assistance from family or government loans and programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, while Whitney Buehler was in Croatia on her honeymoon, the back of her mind was home in Atlanta gearing up for a summer of house hunting.

articles.headline: Man of the People? Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.
articles.snippet: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: He worked a throng of screaming fans in Dagestan. He hoisted a young girl onto his hip in Kronstadt. He posed shoulder-to-shoulder with seven young siblings, shaking their father’s hand after a naval parade.

articles.headline: Clarence Thomas’s $267,230 R.V. and the Friend Who Financed It
articles.snippet: The vehicle is a key part of the justice’s just-folks persona. It’s also a luxury motor coach that was funded by someone else’s money.
articles.abstract: The vehicle is a key part of the justice’s just-folks persona. It’s also a luxury motor coach that was funded by someone else’s money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas met the recreational vehicle of his dreams in Phoenix, on a November Friday in 1999.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Julie Tate

articles.headline: Automakers Face a Labor Showdown as the E.V. Era Looms
articles.snippet: The United Auto Workers leader vowed to be tougher than his predecessors in contract talks. His initial demands attach big numbers to that promise.
articles.abstract: The United Auto Workers leader vowed to be tougher than his predecessors in contract talks. His initial demands attach big numbers to that promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Detroit may be headed for a tumultuous labor showdown.

articles.headline: How to Catch Pandemic Fraud? Prosecutors Try Novel Methods.
articles.snippet: Strained by limited resources, prosecutors are deploying special teams and nurturing local relationships to catch up to a wave of fraud.
articles.abstract: Strained by limited resources, prosecutors are deploying special teams and nurturing local relationships to catch up to a wave of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are scrambling to recoup billions of dollars in pandemic aid from people who falsely obtained funds from government programs that were intended to keep the economy afloat during the Covid shutdowns.

articles.headline: Schumer Wields Political Heft in Bid for New York Chips Funds
articles.snippet: The Senate majority leader helped deliver billions of dollars in federal funding for semiconductors. Now he’s pushing for his state to reap benefits.
articles.abstract: The Senate majority leader helped deliver billions of dollars in federal funding for semiconductors. Now he’s pushing for his state to reap benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a darkened hotel ballroom in San Jose, Calif., last November, the most powerful players in the semiconductor industry received a familiar sales pitch.

articles.headline: Eight Months Pregnant and Arrested After False Facial Recognition Match
articles.snippet: Porcha Woodruff thought the police who showed up at her door to arrest her for carjacking were joking. She is the first woman known to be wrongfully accused as a result of facial recognition technology.
articles.abstract: Porcha Woodruff thought the police who showed up at her door to arrest her for carjacking were joking. She is the first woman known to be wrongfully accused as a result of facial recognition technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Porcha Woodruff was getting her two daughters ready for school when six police officers showed up at her door in Detroit. They asked her to step outside because she was under arrest for robbery and carjacking.

articles.headline: Anguish in Camelot: Kennedy Campaign Roils Storied Political Family
articles.snippet: The presidential bid by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has tested the bonds of an iconic Democratic clan that does not want him to run and does not know what to do about it.
articles.abstract: The presidential bid by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has tested the bonds of an iconic Democratic clan that does not want him to run and does not know what to do about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Schlossberg had had enough. The only grandson of President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Schlossberg had been watching the presidential campaign of his cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr. with increasing dismay.

articles.headline: Indiana Tests if the Heartland Can Transform Into a Chip Hub
articles.snippet: The state has little experience with semiconductors, but the Biden administration has promised to unleash opportunity in “the heartland of America” through the $52 billion CHIPS Act.
articles.abstract: The state has little experience with semiconductors, but the Biden administration has promised to unleash opportunity in “the heartland of America” through the $52 billion CHIPS Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past 14 months, Indiana began converting 10,000 acres of corn and bean fields into an innovation park. State leaders met with the chief executives of semiconductor giants in South Korea, Taiwan and Japan. And they hosted top Biden administration officials to show off a $100 million expansion of chip research and development facilities at a local university.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Putin’s Forever War
articles.snippet: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
articles.abstract: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
articles.lead_paragraph: Through towering pine forests and untouched meadows, the road to Lake Baikal in southern Siberia winds past cemeteries where bright plastic flowers mark the graves of Russians killed in Ukraine. Far from the Potemkin paradise of Moscow, the war is ever visible.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: Xi Rebuilt the Military to His Liking. Now a Shake-Up Threatens Its Image.
articles.snippet: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
articles.abstract: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Xi Jinping has entrenched his hold on power in China, he has likened himself to a physician, eradicating the toxins of corruption and disloyalty that threaten the rule of the Communist Party. And his signature project for over a decade has been bringing to heel the once extravagantly corrupt military leadership.

articles.headline: A Zoom Call, Fake Names and an A.I. Presentation Gone Awry
articles.snippet: A.I. start-ups are competing fiercely with one another as a race to get ahead in the technology intensifies.
articles.abstract: A.I. start-ups are competing fiercely with one another as a race to get ahead in the technology intensifies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arthur AI, an artificial intelligence company in New York, received a message in April last year from a start-up called OneOneThree. Yan Fung, OneOneThree’s head of technology, said he was interested in buying Arthur AI’s technology and wanted a demonstration.

articles.headline: How Long Will Interest Rates Stay High?
articles.snippet: It’s pricey to borrow to buy a business, car or home these days. Interest rates are expected to fall in coming years — how much is up for debate.
articles.abstract: It’s pricey to borrow to buy a business, car or home these days. Interest rates are expected to fall in coming years — how much is up for debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Alice Mills was thinking of selling her veterinary practice in Lexington, Ky., this year, but she decided to put the move off because she worried that it would be difficult to sell in an era of rising interest rates.

articles.headline: Is Social Justice for the Birds? Audubon Attempts an Answer.
articles.snippet: A battle over the group namesake’s ties to slavery grew into a conflict over diversity, highlighting complications that have arisen in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death.
articles.abstract: A battle over the group namesake’s ties to slavery grew into a conflict over diversity, highlighting complications that have arisen in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the same day George Floyd was murdered by a police officer on a Minneapolis street — Memorial Day, 2020 —  Christian Cooper was searching for songbirds in Central Park. Mr. Cooper, who is Black, would be vaulted to fame after a run-in with a white woman who called the police and falsely claimed he was threatening her when he asked her to leash her dog.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Not a Sprint,’ Ukraine’s Marines Insist. ‘It’s a Marathon.’
articles.snippet: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
articles.abstract: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have NATO equipment and Western training. Some have English-speaking commanders, unusual in the Ukrainian military, and even an American-accented, evangelical chaplain.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

articles.headline: Crypto’s Next Craze? Orbs That Scan Your Eyeballs.
articles.snippet: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, has started Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project that aims to scan billions of human irises.
articles.abstract: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, has started Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project that aims to scan billions of human irises.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening last month, a crowd of cryptocurrency enthusiasts gathered at an art gallery in downtown Manhattan. They were greeted by a scene from science fiction.
